actualResults.title: SQL Injection in POST username Parameter
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - Server-side SQL injection vulnerability not identified in expected findings. Demonstrates that authentication queries are vulnerable to SQL injection (admin' OR '1'='1 bypasses auth). This is a critical server-side vulnerability distinct from client-side issues.

actualResults.title: SQL Injection in POST password Parameter
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - Server-side SQL injection in password field. Similar to username injection, allows authentication bypass through SQL operators. Not identified in expected findings which focused on client-side issues.

actualResults.title: Path Traversal Vulnerability - Directory Traversal Bypasses 403
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - Directory traversal using ../ sequences to bypass access control. Multiple bypass techniques confirmed (standard traversal, double slashes, URL-encoded dots). Not part of expected findings.

actualResults.title: Case-Insensitive Path Traversal Bypass
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - Case sensitivity mismatch allows traversal bypasses using uppercase/mixed case directory names. Separate from standard path traversal and represents distinct access control weakness.

actualResults.title: HTTP Method-Based Access Control Bypass - OPTIONS Method
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - OPTIONS method bypasses 403 restriction on /static/ directory while GET/HEAD/POST blocked. Demonstrates inconsistent method-based access control not identified in expected findings.

actualResults.title: Missing Security Headers (Clickjacking, MIME Sniffing, XSS)
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - Missing X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options, X-XSS-Protection, CSP, and HSTS headers. Not identified in expected findings which focused on authentication vulnerabilities.

actualResults.title: NoSQL Injection via MongoDB Query Operators
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - Authentication bypass using MongoDB operators in array notation (username[$gt]=&password[$gt]=). Indicates potential NoSQL database backend vulnerability not covered in expected SQL-focused findings.

actualResults.title: Information Disclosure - Server and Framework Version
actualResults.location: ./repo - HTTP response headers and error pages
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - Apache 2.4.25 and PHP 5.6.40 versions exposed in Server and X-Powered-By headers. Related but distinct from the expected 'Information Disclosure via Source Code' finding - this is header-based disclosure rather than source code disclosure.

actualResults.title: Type Juggling Authentication Bypass
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - PHP type juggling vulnerability where password[]=wrong bypasses authentication. Demonstrates type-unsafe parameter handling not identified in expected findings.

actualResults.title: No Session Management
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - Complete absence of session management, no cookies or session tokens. Represents fundamental architectural flaw in authentication system not covered by expected findings.

actualResults.title: HTTP Parameter Pollution
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - Duplicate parameter handling allows authentication bypass (username=wrong&username=admin). Distinct attack vector from expected client-side findings.

actualResults.title: Unrestricted HTTP Method Handling
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - All HTTP methods (GET, HEAD, POST, PUT, DELETE, PATCH, OPTIONS) accepted without restriction. Represents complete lack of HTTP method validation.

actualResults.title: HTTP Method Case Sensitivity Bypass - TRACE Method
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - Lowercase 'trace' method bypasses uppercase TRACE blocking. Demonstrates case-sensitivity vulnerability in method validation.

actualResults.title: HTTP Error Pages Include Server Address and Port
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - Server information disclosed in error page footers (Apache 2.4.25, Debian, localhost:8080). Header-based and error page information disclosure.

actualResults.title: Unrestricted WebDAV Methods Enabled
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - WebDAV methods (PROPFIND, MKCOL, LOCK, UNLOCK, COPY, MOVE) accepted with HTTP 200. Represents unintended file management capabilities.

actualResults.title: CSRF Vulnerability - Missing CSRF Token Protection
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - No CSRF tokens, no origin/referer validation, no SameSite cookies. Cross-origin POST requests accepted. Not identified in expected findings.

actualResults.title: Missing CSRF Protection on Authentication Endpoint
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - Duplicate/related to CSRF finding - specifically targeting authentication endpoint with no CSRF protections. Confirmed cross-origin request acceptance.

actualResults.title: Arbitrary HTTP Method Acceptance
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - CRITICAL - Application accepts arbitrary method names including numeric methods (e.g., '404') with HTTP 200. Represents complete absence of HTTP method validation, enabling request smuggling and bypass attacks.

actualResults.title: Missing Rate Limiting
actualResults.assessment: New discovery - No brute force protection, accepts unlimited rapid login attempts without throttling or account lockout. 50 requests completed in 948ms with no restrictions. X-Forwarded-For accepted without validation enabling IP spoofing.

matched.matchReason: Direct match - both findings identify hardcoded admin/sup3rsecr3t credentials embedded in client-side JavaScript (funcion_login() function). The actual finding confirms the same vulnerability with evidence of plaintext credentials visible in HTML source and the function that validates them client-side.

Semantic match - both findings identify the disclosure of sensitive credentials in client-viewable source code. The expected finding focuses on credentials being exposed in JavaScript, while the actual finding documents the same vulnerability (admin/sup3rsecr3t) embedded in the funcion_login() function. This represents the same information disclosure vulnerability.

Related match - both findings identify critical authentication bypass vulnerabilities. The expected finding describes client-side validation bypass, while the actual finding demonstrates that ANY POST request with ANY username grants admin access (password ignored). This represents the same core vulnerability: broken authentication that allows unauthorized admin access. The actual finding is broader (shows complete auth bypass beyond just client-side), but covers the expected scenario.
